snippet: The YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, now in Manhattan, and the Lithuanian government have agreed to let the surviving YIVO documents in Lithuania be integrated into a web portal.
abstract: YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, considered the world's foremost collection of Yiddish books and cultural artifacts, and the Lithuanian government agree to allow the surviving YIVO documents in Lithuania be integrated into a web portal; YIVO, whose new home is in New York, was torn apart in 1941 German occupation of Vilna, Lithuania; project is expected to take seven years at cost of $5.25 million.
lead_paragraph: The YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, now in Manhattan, and the Lithuanian government have agreed to let the surviving YIVO documents in Lithuania be integrated into a web portal.

headline.main: Split Up by Holocaust, Top Collection of Yiddish Works Will Reunite Digitally
headline.print_headline: Split Up by Holocaust, Top Collection of Yiddish Works Will Be Reunited Digitally
